choices.text: A - Foramen of Luschka, B - Foramen of Magendie
B - Foramen of Magendie, C - Foramen of Luschka
C - Foramen of Magendie, D - Foramen of Luschka
B - Foramen of Luschka, C - Foramen of Magendie

questions.text: Mark the position of the foramen of Magendie and the foramen of Luschka:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The foramen of Magendie (median aperture) lies at the midline of the roof of the fourth ventricle, allowing cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) to flow into the cisterna magna.

The foramina of Luschka (lateral apertures) is located more laterally, allowing CSF to pass into the subarachnoid space near the cerebellopontine angle.

  • C represents the foramen of Magendie (median, midline)
  • D represents the foramen of Luschka (lateral, paired)

Key Takeaways:

  • Both foramina drain CSF from the fourth ventricle to the subarachnoid space.
  • These apertures are essential in the circulation of CSF from the ventricular system to the external brain surface.

choices.text: B
C
A
D

questions.text: Identify the Putamen
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Putamen is part of the lentiform nucleus and lies lateral to the globus pallidus. In coronal and horizontal sections, it appears as a lens-shaped structure and is located between the globus pallidus and the external capsule.

  • The lentiform nucleus = globus pallidus + putamen
  • The putamen functions in regulating movements and influences various types of learning.

choices.text: A - Superior colliculus, B - Third ventricle, C - Cerebellum, D - Medulla
A- Corpora quadrigemina, B - Fourth ventricle, C - Cerebellum, D - Pons
A - Inferior colliculus, B - Cerebral aqueduct, C - Pons, D - Midbrain
A - Pineal gland, B - Cerebral aqueduct, C - Occipital lobe, D - Pons

questions.text:
Identify the labelled structures in the given sagittal section of the brain:

Which of the following options correctly identifies the labelled structures?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image depicts a mid-sagittal section of the brainstem and posterior cranial fossa. The corpora quadrigemina (A), which includes the superior and inferior colliculi, are dorsal midbrain structures. The fourth ventricle (B) lies between the pons (D) and cerebellum (C), forming part of the CSF circulation system.


  • The fourth ventricle is a diamond-shaped cavity seen in midline sections of the hindbrain.
  • Corpora quadrigemina lie posterior to the cerebral aqueduct and are involved in sensory reflexes.
  • The cerebellum lies dorsal to the fourth ventricle.
  • Pons forms the floor of the fourth ventricle.

choices.text: B - Basal ganglia
C - Cerebral cortex
D - Cerebellum
A - Amygdala

questions.text: Identify the basal ganglia:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The structure labelled B corresponds to the basal ganglia, which are a group of deep grey matter nuclei crucial for the modulation of motor activity and procedural learning.


  • The basal ganglia are situated lateral to the thalamus and deep to the cerebral cortex.
  • Functionally, they are involved in initiating and regulating voluntary motor activity, and abnormalities result in movement disorders.
  • Structures include the caudate nucleus, putamen, and globus pallidus.

Key Takeaways:

  • The basal ganglia are essential for motor control and habit learning.
  • Clinical disorders include Parkinson's, Huntington's, and dystonia.
  • Located deep within the cerebral hemispheres, seen in both coronal and sagittal sections.

choices.text: Adult - Lower border of L1, Infant - Upper border of L3
Adult - Upper border of L3, Infant - Lower border of L1
Adult - Lower border of L3, Infant - Upper border of L1
Adult - Upper border of L1, Infant - Lower border of L1

questions.text: The structure at which the termination of the spinal cord takes place in adults and infants:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In adults, the spinal cord terminates at the lower border of the L1 vertebra, while in infants, it ends higher at the upper border of L3 due to differential growth of the vertebral column compared to the spinal cord.

  • Adult termination: Lower border of L1
  • Infant termination: Upper border of L3
  • Below this point, the spinal nerve roots form a bundle known as the cauda equina, descending to their respective intervertebral foramina.
  • The subarachnoid space extends down to the level of S2, making the lumbar cistern (L2-S2) a safe site for lumbar puncture.
  • The relative ascent of spinal cord termination from L3 (in neonates) to L1 (in adults) is due to faster growth of the vertebral column.
  • Conus medullaris: This is the tapering terminal end of the spinal cord, located at the lower border of L1 in adults and at upper L3 in infants.
  • Filum terminale: A fibrous extension of the pia mater arising from the tip of the conus medullaris, anchoring the spinal cord to the coccyx.
  • Exiting nerve roots: Lumbar, sacral, and coccygeal spinal nerves descend obliquely below the conus medullaris to reach their respective intervertebral foramina, forming the cauda equina.

(Other options are ruled out)

choices.text: Triangular lateral extensions of the pia mater
Triangular lateral extensions of the dura mater
Quadrangular lateral extensions of the pia mater
Extensions of the arachnoid mater

questions.text: The marked ligament is a modification of-
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The denticulate ligament is derived from the pia mater and appears as a series of triangular lateral projections between the dorsal and ventral roots. These extensions serve to stabilise the spinal cord within the dural sac.

  • Origin: Pia mater (not dura or arachnoid)
  • Structure: Triangular sheet-like lateral projections
  • Number: Typically 21 pairs (may vary from 18-24 pairs)
  • Attachments:
    • Superior end: Near the foramen magnum, between the vertebral artery and CN XII
    • Inferior end: Near the conus medullaris (T12-L1), continuous with filum terminale
  • Function: Anchors the spinal cord laterally to the dura mater, helps centre it within the subarachnoid space

Explanation of Other Options:

Triangular lateral extensions of dura mater (Option B): The dura mater is the tough outer meningeal layer and does not form specialised lateral extensions. It provides general protection and forms dural folds (e.g., falx cerebri) but does not give rise to denticle-like structures.

Quadrangular lateral extensions of the pia mater (Option C): Although derived from the pia mater, the denticulate ligaments are specifically triangular, not quadrangular. Each projection has a pointed apex that anchors to the dura.

Extensions of arachnoid mater (Option D): The arachnoid mater is a delicate avascular membrane that loosely surrounds the spinal cord. It forms the arachnoid trabeculae, not dense, ligamentous structures like the denticulate ligaments.

choices.text: Skin → Subcutaneous tissue → Supraspinous ligament → Interspinous ligament → Ligamentum flavum → Epidural space → Dura → Arachnoid
Skin → Supraspinous ligament → Subcutaneous tissue → Interspinous ligament → Ligamentum flavum → Epidural space → Dura → Arachnoid
Skin → Subcutaneous tissue → Supraspinous ligament → Interspinous ligament → Ligamentum flavum → Epidural space → Arachnoid → Dura
Skin → Subcutaneous tissue → Supraspinous ligament → Interspinous ligament → Ligamentum flavum → Dura → Epidural space → Arachnoid

questions.text: The order in which the spinal needle will pierce the lumbar spine is as follows:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The correct sequence of layers traversed during a midline lumbar puncture is:

  • Skin
  • Subcutaneous tissue
  • Supraspinous ligament
  • Interspinous ligament
  • Ligamentum flavum
  • Epidural space
  • Dura mater
  • Arachnoid mater

(Other options are ruled out)

Once the needle passes through the arachnoid, it reaches the subarachnoid space where CSF is collected.

choices.text: Filamentous extension from the conus medullaris to the coccyx
Support and stabilisation of the spinal cord within the vertebral canal
Attaches to the posterior surface of the coccyx
Entirely composed of arachnoid mater

questions.text: What is not true about the marked structure in the image?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The filum terminale is a fibrous extension that stabilises the spinal cord within the vertebral canal by anchoring it to the coccyx. It begins at the conus medullaris and has two distinct parts:

  • Filum terminale internum (pial part): Located within the dural sac, formed from the pia mater
  • Filum terminale externum (dural part): Continuation outside the dural sac to the coccyx, surrounded by dura mater

It is not formed from arachnoid mater, making Option D incorrect.

Explanation of Other Options:

Filamentous extension from the conus medullaris to the coccyx (Option A): Correct; it extends caudally from the conus to the coccyx.

Support and stabilisation to the spinal cord (Option B): Correct; prevents vertical displacement of the cord.

Attaches to the posterior surface of the coccyx (Option C): Correct; filum terminale externum pierces the dural sac and attaches to the coccyx.

choices.text: L1-L2 in both adults and children
L3-L4 in adults; L4-L5 in children
L2-L3 in adults; L5-S1 in children
L2-L3 in both adults and children

questions.text: What is the ideal intervertebral level for lumbar puncture in adults and children, respectively?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Lumbar puncture (LP) is performed below the level of the spinal cord termination to avoid cord injury.

  • In adults, the spinal cord typically ends at the lower border of the L1 vertebra, so LP is ideally done at L3-L4 or L4-L5 interspaces
  • In children, the conus medullaris may extend lower, up to L3, so the puncture is safely done at L4-L5.

The needle is inserted between adjacent spinous processes, passing through:

Skin → Subcutaneous tissue → Supraspinous ligament → Interspinous ligament → Ligamentum flavum → Epidural space → Dura mater → Arachnoid mater → Subarachnoid space (where CSF is sampled).

Explanation of Other Options:

L1-L2 in both (Option A): Unsafe in both groups - risk of spinal cord injury.

L2-L3 in adults or children (Options C, D): Still near conus medullaris in children; not preferred.

choices.text: Meningitis
Epilepsy
Tuberculous meningitis
Multiple sclerosis

questions.text: Lumbar puncture is useful in the diagnosis of all the following except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Lumbar puncture is a key diagnostic procedure for evaluating central nervous system (CNS) infections and inflammatory conditions, as it provides direct access to cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). However, it is not indicated in epilepsy, as seizures are diagnosed clinically and with EEG, not by CSF analysis.

choices.text: Afferent neurons arising from the skin overlying the trapezius muscle
Somatic motor neurons supplying the levator scapulae muscle
Afferent neurons from the skin of the anterior chest wall
Somatic motor neurons supplying the trapezius muscle

questions.text: Which of the following is a source of axons found in the dorsal primary ramus of the 4th thoracic spinal nerve?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The dorsal (posterior) primary rami of spinal nerves innervate the intrinsic (true) back muscles (e.g., erector spinae, splenius) and the skin of the medial back. These rami contain both motor and sensory axons:

  • Afferent sensory axons from the skin overlying the back
  • Efferent somatic motor axons to the true back muscles

The trapezius, although a back muscle anatomically, is not a true back muscle embryologically; it is innervated by the spinal accessory nerve (CN XI). Muscles like the rhomboids and levator scapulae are innervated by ventral rami, not dorsal.

Explanation of Other Options:

Levator scapulae (Option B): Motor innervation is via the dorsal scapular nerve (C5) and ventral rami of C3-C4, not dorsal rami.

Skin of anterior chest (Option C): Innervated by ventral rami via intercostal nerves, not dorsal rami.

Trapezius muscle motor (Option D): Innervated by cranial nerve XI (accessory nerve), not spinal dorsal or ventral rami.

choices.text: L3
L4
L5
S1

questions.text: A man has a herniated intervertebral disc between the L4 and L5 vertebrae. If this disc compresses the spinal nerve within the intervertebral foramen immediately posterior to this disc, which spinal nerve is most likely affected?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In the lumbar region, spinal nerves exit below the vertebra of the corresponding number. However, due to the descending course of nerve roots within the cauda equina, a herniated disc typically affects the nerve root traversing downward to exit below the next vertebra, not the one exiting at that level. (Other options are ruled out)

  • A disc herniation at L4-L5 compresses the L5 spinal nerve.
  • The L4 nerve root exits above the L4-L5 disc and thus escapes compression.
  • The L5 root travels downward and is vulnerable within the lateral recess and intervertebral foramen.

Pathophysiology:

The nucleus pulposus (gelatinous core of the intervertebral disc) can herniate through a weakened or ruptured annulus fibrosus, often posterolaterally. This herniation compresses the spinal nerve roots within the vertebral canal or foramen, resulting in radiculopathy, manifesting as pain, numbness, or weakness along the nerve distribution.

choices.text: Arachnoid
Denticulate ligament
Periosteum
Perineurium

questions.text: A CT myelogram shows dye leakage along spinal nerves in the mid-cervical region on the right side. Which meningeal layer must be torn for the dye to leak out?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The dye in a myelogram is injected into the subarachnoid space; hence, rupture of the arachnoid mater is necessary for it to leak out.

  • The arachnoid mater is the thin, avascular meningeal layer that lines the inside of the dura and encloses the subarachnoid space, which contains CSF.
  • A myelogram involves contrast injection into the subarachnoid space.
  • Any leakage of dye from the spinal canal indicates a breach in the arachnoid layer, permitting the escape of CSF and dye.
  • The spinal cord ends at L1-L2 in adults. Hence, lumbar punctures are safely performed at L3-L4 or L4-L5, where the roots float in CSF and are not injured.
  • L4 level is identified by drawing a line between the iliac crests, which intersects the L4 spinous process.

Explanation of Other Options:

Denticulate ligament (Option B): Specialisation of pia mater; stabilises the spinal cord laterally. Not part of CSF containment, hence not responsible for dye leakage.

Periosteum (Option C): Dense connective tissue lining bones; not related to the meninges or CSF containment.

Perineurium (Option D): Connective tissue sheath surrounding a bundle of peripheral nerve fibres; not associated with CSF or meningeal layers.

choices.text: Exhibits both a cervical and lumbar enlargement
Has a modification of neural tissue extending from its termination to the coccyx ligament
Gives origin to most of the cauda equina
Is found at its lowest extent at S2

questions.solution:
Explanation:

The conus medullaris is the tapered, distal end of the spinal cord proper, typically located at the level of the inferior border of L1 or superior border of L2. Most of the cauda equina arises from the conus medullaris and descends obliquely to reach the appropriate intervertebral foramina.

  • Location: Usually at the L1-L2 vertebral level
  • Function: Gives rise to the lumbar, sacral, and coccyx nerve roots of the cauda equina
  • Relation to Filum Terminale: The filum terminale internum, a fibrous extension of pia mater, continues from the conus medullaris and extends to the S2 level; beyond that, the filum terminale externum (dural component) attaches to the coccyx, forming the coccygeal ligament.
  • Note: The dural sac ends at S2; hence, spinal taps are done below L2 to avoid injury to the cord
  • Key differentiation: The conus is not the site of cervical/lumbar enlargements (Option A), and does not extend modified neural tissue to the coccyx (Option B)

Explanation of Other Options:

Exhibits both a cervical and lumbar enlargement (Option A): The cervical and lumbar enlargements refer to the broader regions of the spinal cord itself, not the conus medullaris.

Has a modification of neural tissue extending from its termination to the coccyx ligament (Option B): The extension to the coccyx is the filum terminale, which is non-neural, derived from meninges (pia/dura), not neural tissue.

It is found at its lowest extent at S2 (Option D): The conus ends around L1-L2, not S2; it's the dural sac that extends to S2.

choices.text: Laminae, pedicles and ligamenta flavum
Laminae, spinous processes and ligamenta flava
Pedicles, spinous processes and posterior longitudinal ligament
Transverse processes, pedicles and ligamenta flavum

questions.text: In order to expose the spinal cord from the posterior side, it is necessary to remove the:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

To access the spinal cord posteriorly during dissection or surgery, the overlying laminae, spinous processes, and the ligamenta flava (which span between the laminae) must be removed. These structures form the posterior wall of the vertebral canal and must be resected to reach the spinal cord within the subarachnoid space.

Additionally, the supraspinous and interspinous ligaments, located between the spinous processes, are also usually removed as part of the approach.

Explanation of Other Options:

Laminae, pedicles and ligamenta flavum (Option A): The pedicles form the lateral walls of the vertebral canal and are not removed to access the spinal cord posteriorly.

Pedicles, spinous processes and posterior longitudinal ligament (Option C): The posterior longitudinal ligament lies anterior to the spinal cord, along the posterior surfaces of vertebral bodies - not part of the posterior approach.

Transverse processes, pedicles and ligamenta flavum (Option D): Transverse processes are lateral extensions and not involved in the posterior exposure of the cord. Pedicles, again, are not typically removed.

choices.text: The spinal cord ends at the level of S2 in adults
The dural sac and subarachnoid space terminate at the level of L2
The filum terminale externum extends from S2 to the coccyx
The spinal cord terminates at the disc between L5 and S1

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the termination of spinal structures is true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The filum terminale is a fibrous extension of the spinal cord that anchors it distally. It is subdivided into two parts:

  • Filum terminale internum: A continuation of the pia mater, extending from the conus medullaris (L1-L2) to S2, within the dural sac.
  • Filum terminale externum (coccygeal ligament): A continuation of dura mater, beginning from the end of the dural sac at S2, and attaching to the coccyx.

Key terminations:

  • Spinal cord ends at L1-L2 in adults (conus medullaris)
  • Dural sac and subarachnoid space end at S2
  • Filum terminale externum continues below S2, stabilising the cord to the coccyx.

Explanation of Other Options:

The spinal cord ends at the level of S2 in adults (Option A): The spinal cord typically ends at the level of the intervertebral disc between L1 and L2 in adults, forming the conus medullaris. Below this, the cauda equina and filum terminale continue within the subarachnoid space and dural sac.

The dural sac and subarachnoid space terminate at the level of L2 (Option B): While the spinal cord ends at L1-L2, the dural sac and subarachnoid space containing CSF continue down to S2, providing a safe zone for lumbar puncture.

The spinal cord terminates at the disc between L5 and S1 (Option D): This is well below the actual termination of the spinal cord. At this level, only nerve roots (cauda equina) and the filum terminale are present within the dural sac.

choices.text: Anterior spinal artery
Posterior spinal artery
Segmental medullary artery
Artery of Adamkiewicz

questions.text: A 62-year-old male patient undergoes surgery for a thoracic aortic aneurysm. Postoperatively, he develops sudden flaccid paraplegia with loss of pain and temperature sensation below the level of the lesion, but proprioception remains intact. Which artery is most likely involved in this complication?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The artery of Adamkiewicz is a major segmental medullary artery that reinforces the anterior spinal artery, especially in the lower thoracic and lumbar spinal cord. Damage to this vessel during thoracic aortic surgery can cause anterior spinal artery syndrome, leading to motor paralysis and loss of pain and temperature sensation below the lesion, sparing proprioception.

Explanation of Other Options:

Anterior spinal artery (Option A): Supplies the anterior two-thirds of the spinal cord but is reinforced by segmental medullary arteries like the artery of Adamkiewicz.

Posterior spinal artery (Option B): Supplies the posterior one-third of the spinal cord, responsible for proprioception; infarction here causes sensory (not motor) loss.

Segmental medullary artery (Option C): A general term for feeder arteries; the artery of Adamkiewicz is the most significant among them in the thoracolumbar region.

choices.text: Temperature
Light touch
Discriminative touch
Pain

questions.text: First-order neurons synapsing in the spinal nucleus are conveying all of the following information except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Discriminative touch is not mediated by first-order neurons that synapse in the spinal nucleus. It is instead relayed through the dorsal column-medial lemniscal pathway, which synapses in the medulla.

  • The spinal nucleus of the trigeminal nerve receives input primarily for pain, temperature, and crude (light) touch.
  • These modalities enter via the first-order neuron, descend in the spinal tract, and synapse in the spinal nucleus.
  • Discriminative touch, vibration, and conscious proprioception ascend through the dorsal columns and do not synapse in the spinal nucleus.

After entering the spinal cord, the first-order neurons synapse (in the nucleus proprius), and the second-order neurons decussate via the anterior white commissure.

  • These second-order neurons ascend, synapsing in the VPL of the thalamus.
  • Incoming first-order neurons can ascend or descend via the Lissauer tract.

Explanation of Other Options:

Temperature (Option A): Carried by first-order neurons that synapse in the spinal nucleus; part of the lateral spinothalamic tract.

Light touch (Option B): Transmitted via the anterior spinothalamic tract; first-order neurons synapse in the spinal nucleus.

Pain (Option D): Transmitted via lateral spinothalamic tract; first-order neurons synapse in the spinal nucleus.
